clinical_study.brief_title: The Effect of Vitamin K Supplementation on Bone Health in Adult Crohn's Disease Patients
clinical_study.official_title: The Effect of Vitamin K Supplementation on Bone Health Indices in Adult Crohn's Disease

brief_summary.textblock: To assess the impact of a 12 month vitamin K supplementation intervention on bone health in adult Crohn's disease patients

detailed_description.textblock: To assess the impact of 12 months of vitamin K1 supplementation (plus vitamin D and calcium supplementation to avoid deficiency of these problematic nutrients) at a level which leads to dramatically (i.e greater than 70%) reduced levels of undercarboxylated osteocalcin - a functional marker of vitamin K status, on vitamin K status, the rate of bone formation and bone resorption, using biochemical markers of bone turnover, and bone mineral density in adult patients with longstanding Crohn's disease.

primary_outcome.description: Measurement of carboxylated and undercarboxylated osteocalcin (expressed as %) as a senstive functional marker of vitamin K status.

secondary_outcome.description: Measurement of serum 25-Hydroxy vitamin D as status measure
Measurement of intact parathyroid hormone to determine hyperparathyroidism, hypercalcemia, vitamin D deficiency
For standardisation of urinary NTx measurement
Determination of serum phylloquinone by HPLC

secondary_outcome.measure: Biochemical markers of bone turnover (BAP, CTx, NTx)
secondary_outcome.description: Use of biochemical markers of bone turnover to assess the effect of supplementation on bone health.
Measurement of bone mineral density (BMD) by iDEXA

secondary_outcome.measure: Food Frequency Questionnaire (FFQ) for habitual vitamin K, vitamin D and calcium intakes
secondary_outcome.description: Food frequency questionnaire (FFQ) to estimate habitual vitamin K (vitamin D and calcium) status, cross-sectionally at baseline.

intervention.description: 1000 mcg phylloquinone (vitamin K1) once daily for 12 months

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- long-standing Crohn's disease - disease diagnosis > 5 years
- in clinical remission at baseline - Harvey-Bradshaw score (< 5)
- aged between 18-70 years
Exclusion Criteria:
- use of steroid medications to treat disease or flare up
- use of blood thinning medications (warfarin, heparin, asprin, dicoumarol derivatives) which may influence vitamin K metabolism
- use of bisphosphonates, calcitonin medications (to treat osteoporosis)
- use of experimental drugs (in the last 30 days) or inclusion in another intervention trial
- bone mineral density < -2.5 (indicative of osteoporosis) or previous diagnosis of osteoporosis
- use of vitamin/mineral/fish liver oil dietary supplements
- use of other alternative supplements (i.e herbal)
- if the patient is under 18 or over 70 years of age
- presence of a significant acute or chronic coexisting illness (cardiovascular, immunological or a condition which in the investigator's judgement, contraindicates involvement in the study)
- presence of malignant or any concomitant end-stage organ disease
